reference: Volume Five, Issue Forty-Six, File 15 of 28
title: visanetoperations; part1
historical_context: This article is part of a series that delves into the technical specifications and operational details of VisaNet's second-generation authorization systems, reflecting the growing complexity of electronic payment systems in the early 1990s.
target_audience: Security professionals, hackers interested in payment systems, and those studying the evolution of electronic transactions.
short_summary: This article outlines the external interface specifications for VisaNet's second-generation authorization record formats, detailing the request and response structures for Point-Of-Sale (POS) transactions. It serves as a technical guide for developers and security researchers interested in payment processing systems.
summary:
In 'visanetoperations; part1', icejey provides a comprehensive overview of the authorization record formats used in VisaNet's second-generation POS systems. The article begins with an introduction to the request and response record formats, emphasizing the importance of understanding these structures for developing new applications. It details the various data elements required for authorization requests, including merchant identification, transaction codes, and customer data fields, while also addressing the significance of message delimiters and field separators in ensuring data integrity during transactions.

The article further elaborates on the character code definitions and the specific requirements for different transaction types, such as credit and debit card transactions. By dissecting the technical specifications, icejey not only highlights the intricacies of VisaNet's operations but also underscores the evolving landscape of electronic payments, making this article a valuable resource for those involved in security research and the development of payment processing applications.
